abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Development Corporation
            Project in Nepal was achieved. The utilization of the credit
            was slower than anticipated due mainly to the difficult
            industrial and overall economic environment in Nepal. The
            major problems encountered included the long delay and
            inadequate management of project implementations. On hind
            sight, this was due to the escalating interest and
            inadequate financial commitment of project sponsors who
            lacked experience in industry. In comparison to other
            development financing institution, the Nepal Industrial
            Development Corporation (NIDC) has relied heavily on equity
            financing from government and/or government-owned
            institutions. NIDC is a stronger institution with suitable
            policies, more streamlined organization and procedures,
            higher standards, and improved staffing policies and
            training. In general, the objectives of this project were
            met although with some difficulties and over a longer period
            than anticipated.

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed credit would be used to
            meet 100 percent of the foreign exchange expenditures for
            directly imported capital goods and services for subprojects
            sponsored by private productive enterprises to be broadly
            defined to include not only manufacturing, but also
            agro-industries, construction, and tourism projects.
